column10: Saadia Gaon was a philosopher, halachist, biblical commentator, polemicist, grammarian and pre-eminent Jewish leader of Mesopotamian Jewry. His best-known work, Emunot vDeot, was the first systematic work of Jewish philosophy. His ground-breaking work in Hebrew grammar was part of his polemic against Karaism. He was the first Torah sage to write extensively in Judeo-Arabic, In 928 he was appointed Gaon (preeminant spiritual and temporal leader) of the academy of Sura, and subsequently, his influence spread throughout the Jewish world.

Rabbi Shelomo ben Yitzhak, best known by the acronym Rashi, authored the most authoritative commentaries on the Tanakh and Talmud. He was also a halakhist who authored responsa. Rashi is known as the father of all commentators. There are no extant manuscripts of his works copied prior to his death. Rashi was an early and very influential medieval Torah and Talmud commentator who lived in France. Rashi's commentary on the Bible is often considered an indispensable tool for Torah study. He described his aim as clarifying the "peshat" or "plain-sense" meaning of each verse.
column11: רבי שלמה בן יצחק, הידוע על פי ראשי התיבות רש"י, חיבר את הפירושים הסמכותיים ביותר לתנ"ך ולתלמוד. רש"י עסק גם בפסקי הלכה וחיבר שו"תים. הוא ידוע כ"אבי כל הפרשנים". לא נמצאים בידינו העתקים של כתבי יד שלו מלפני מותו. רש"י חי בצרפת והיה פרשן תנ"ך ותלמוד קדום ובעל השפעה רבה. פירושו של רש"י על התנ"ך נחשב לעתים קרובות כלי הכרחי ללימוד תורה. המטרה שלו הייתה הבהרת הפשט, המשמעות הפשוטה של כל פסוק.

column10: Rabbi Meir ben Shmuel was a French rabbi and tosafist. He was one of the founders of the Tosafost school and approach to Talmudic commentary. He was a son-in-law of Rashi, and three of his sons, Rashbam, Rivam and Rabbenu Tam, were amongst the greatest of talmudists and tosafists, and leaders of their generation.
column25: Four sons, Rabbenu Tam, Rashbam, Isaac ben Meir, Solomon ben Meir

column2: Moshe ben Maimon, Maimonides, Moses Maimonides
column10: Rambam (Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon), was perhaps the greatest intellectual and spiritual figure of post-Talmudic Judaism. He wrote indispensible works of philosophy, halachah, commentary, responsa. Born in Spain, his family fled while he was still a youth. After an extended period in Morocco, he settled in Egypt, where he became Nagid (leader) of the Jewish community. All his works werer foundational in their field. His commentary to the Mishnah was the first comprehensive commentary on the entire Mishnah. His great work of philosophy, Moreh Nevuchim, spawned an entire discipline and had incalculable influence upon enthusiastic promoters and vehement opponents alike. His code of law, Mishneh Torah, is the first and unsurpassed comprehesive code, covering all areas of Jewish law and practice. His medical writings - Rambam served as court physician to the Muslim leader Saladin - had a lasting impact. All of his works were written in Judeo-Arabic except for Mishneh Torah, which was written in a Hebrew of exquisite felicity. The precision of his expression is legendary. His descendents served as Negidim of Egypt for another four generations.

Rabbi Moshe ben Nachman authored commentaries on the Torah and the Talmud. He was a halakhist who wrote responsa and stand alone works on Halakhic issues as well as works on mysticism, science and philosophy.  Ramban was a Spanish scholar of Bible, Talmud, and Jewish Law.  Ramban's commentary on the Torah often critiques earlier commentaries, and incoporates Kabbalistic teachings.
column11: רבי משה בן נחמן חיבר פירושים על התורה והתלמוד. הוא היה איש הלכה שכתב שו"תים וחיבורים עצמאיים בנושאים הלכתיים, כמו גם חיבורים על מיסטיקה, מדע ופילוסופיה. הרמב"ן (שנפטר בשנת 1270) היה תלמיד חכם ספרדי שעסק בתנ"ך, תלמוד והלכה. פירושו של הרמב"ן על התורה לעתים קרובות מבקר פירושים קודמים, ומשלב את תורת קבלה.

column10: Rabbi Sh'muel ben Meir was the grandson of Rashi. He authored a commentary on the Torah that clung strictly to the concept of p'shat sometimes at the expense of received rabbinic traditions. He also wrote a commentary on portions of the Talmud. Rashbam was a French Torah and Talmud commentator. Rashbam's commentary on the Torah provides a detailed "peshat" or "plain-sense" explanation of verse in the Bible.
column11: רבי שמואל בן מאיר היה נכדו של רש"י. הוא חיבר פירוש על התורה שדבק בקפדנות במושג ה"פשט", לפעמים על חשבון מסורות רבניות מקובלות. הוא כתב גם פירוש על חלקים של התלמוד. רשב"ם (שנפטר בסביבות 1174) היה פרשן תורה ותלמוד צרפתי. פירושו של רשב"ם על התורה מספק "פשט" מפורט של פסוק בתנ"ך.
column25: Had several students cf. Norman Golb

column2: Yonah Gerondi, Yonah ben Abraham Gerondi
column10: Rabbeinu Yonah of Gerondi was a Spanish rabbi, talmudist and ethicist. His best-known work is Sha'arei Teshuva, a comprehensive work on repentence and a much-studied and quoted work over the generations He also wrote chiddushim on a number of tractates, quoted by contemporaries and later authors. He was one of the most prominent of the opponents the Rambam's philosophical works, signing a ban on their study. When the sustained attacks on the Rambam's works culminated in a public burning of wagon-loads of Talmud by Christian authorities, Rabbeinu Yonah publicly admitted his error in involved outside players, and gave Rambam a prominent and revered place in his teaching. It is surmised that this turn of events motivated Rabbeinu Yonah to write Sha'arei Teshuva.

Avraham ben Meir was born in Spain but travelled extensively throughout his life. A gifted polymath he wrote an extensive commentary on the torah as well as on grammar, philosophy, astronomy, medicine, and mathematics. His poetry is still read and sung as part of the regular liturgy. Ibn Ezra was a Spanish Torah commentator, who also wrote works on a number of other subjects, including Hebrew grammar and philosophy.  Ibn Ezra's Bible commentary often focuses on grammatical explanations and on the literal meaning of verses.
column11: אברהם בן מאיר נולד בספרד אבל נסע רבות במהלך חייו. איש אשכולות מוכשר, אבן עזרא כתב פרשנות נרחבת על התורה, כמו גם על דקדוק, פילוסופיה, אסטרונומיה, רפואה ומתמטיקה. השירה שלו עדיין נקראת ומושרת כחלק מן התפילה הקבועה. אבן עזרא (שנפטר בסביבות 1167) היה פרשן תורה ספרדי, שכתב גם חיבורים על כמה נושאים אחרים, לרבות דקדוק עברית ופילוסופיה. פרשנות המקרא של אבן עזרא לעתים קרובות מתמקדת בהסברים דקדוקיים ובמשמעות המילולית של פסוקים.
column25: Several people have the same name as him including the famous Moses Ibn Ezra, but it is disputed if they were related in more modern scholarship. Further research is necesary. He son was Isaac ibn Ezra.

column10: Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz was the Chief Rabbi of Prague who wrote a commentary on the Torah, Keli Yakar (a precious vessel) as well as a number of other collections of homilies sermons. Rabbi Luntschitz was a Polish rabbi and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary, Kli Yakar. Keli Yakar is a commentary on the Torah written in a homiletical style.
column11: רבי שלמה אפרים מלונטשיץ היה הרב הראשי של פראג והוא כתב את הפירוש "כלי יקר" על התורה, וכן כמה אוספים אחרים של דרשות. הרבי מלונטשיץ (שנפטר בשנת 1619) היה רב פולני ונואם, והוא ידוע בעיקר בזכות פרשנותו לתורה. ה"כלי יקר" הוא פירוש על התורה שכתוב בסגנון של מדרש.

column10: Rabbi Ovadia ben Yaakov Sforno wrote a commentary on the Torah that sticks to the pshat school. He also wrote works on philosophy and commentaries on a number of books of Tanakh. Sforno is also quoted in responsa of contemporary authorities who consulted him on issues of halakha. Rabbi Ovadiah ben Ya'akov Seforno (d. 1550) was an Italian exegete, philosopher, and physician. Seforno's Torah commentary focuses on the literal meaning of the text, avoids kabbalistic explanations, and sometimes incorporates his knowledge of medicine to help explain verses.
column11: רבי עובדיה בן יעקב ספורנו כתב פירוש על התורה שדבק בדוקטורינת ה"פשט". הוא כתב גם חיבורים בפילוסופיה ופירושים על כמה מספרי התנ"ך. ספורנו מצוטט אף בשו"תים של חכמים בני זמננו שנעזרו בו בענייני הלכה. רבי עובדיה בן יעקב ספורנו (שנפטר ב-1550) חי באיטליה ופעל כדרשן, פילוסוף ורופא. פירוש ספורנו לתורה מתמקד במשמעות המילולית של הכתוב, נמנע מהסברים מתורת הקבלה, ולעתים אף מכיל ידע רפואי כדי להסביר פסוקים מסוימים.

column10: Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Adret (Rashba)  was a Spanish rabbi, talmudist, halachist and community leader in 14th centurry. He lived his entire life in Barcelona. He is considered the most outstanding student of the Ramban, and continued his approach in Talmudic exposition. His yeshiva drew exceptional students from throughout the Jewish world, including quite a number from Germany. He functioned as chief rabbi of Spain and wrote over 1000 responsa to individuals and communities throughout the Jewish world. He was involved in opposition to the Rambam's philosophical writings and prohibited study of philosophy under the age of 25. He also defended Judaism Christian and Moslem polemicists, and vigorously opposed the activity of R. Avraham Abulafia. He responded vigorously in his own defense to the often strident comments of R. Aharon Halevy on his work, Torat HaBayit.
Rabbi Yehudah ben Natan (Rivan) was a French rabbi, talmudist and early tosafist. He was a son-in-law of Rashi and in certain senses extended his work. He is quoted in many places in Tosafot.

Rabbi Eliezer ben Natan (Ra'avan) was a German rabbi, halakhist and commentator. His contemporaries and successors refer him as an authoritative transmitter and decisor of Jewish tradition and practice. Among his decendants and relatives were some of the great rabbinic figures of the next generations. He was one of the first Ashkenazic scholars to quote extensively from the Talmudic commentary of Rabbeynu Chananel. He was also the first German scholar to pen commentaries on piyyut.

Rabbi Eliezer ben Yoel Halevi (Ra'avyah) was a German rabbi, halachist and talmudist. Wandering between communities in Germany and France, he refused to serve in a formal rabbinic until poverty compelled him to accept a rabbinic position in Cologne, where he became famous.  His halachic works were considered authoritative and indispensiblle to his and subsequent generations, His brother's martyrdom caused him to grieve so intensely that his vision was subsequently impaired, and he dictated his later works to students. He was also active as as tosafist.

Rabbi Yaakov ben Meir (Rabbenu Tam was a French rabbi, halakhic authority, liturgical poet and the greatest of the Tosafists. His renown extended well beyond France and Germany to Spain and beyond. His dispute with his grandfather, Rashi, regarding the order of the passages contained in the head-worn tefillin continues to impact daily Jewish practice to this day. He narrowly escaped death at the hands of Crusaders. He befriended Ibn Ezra during the latter's stay in France, and they maintained a subsequent correspondence.

column2: Nissim of Gerona, Nissim ben Reuven
column10: Rabbi Nissim ben Reuven (Ran) was a Spanish rabbi, talmudist and philosopher and the pre-eminent Spanish halakhic authority of his generation. His commentaries to the Talmud and Hilchot  HaRif are main elements of yeshiva curriculum to this day. He establish his yeshiva and Beit Din in Barcelona. Like his predecessor, Rashba, Ran's renown extended to Jewish communities well beyond Spain, who address their questions to him and sought his guidance. He was not inclined toward the Kabbalah.

Rabbi Aharon HaLevi (Ra'ah) was a Spanish rabbi, talmudist, halakhist and critic of Rashba's Torat HaBayit.  Ascription to him of authorship of Sefer HaChinukh has been undermined and, of late, refuted.

Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva) was a Spanish rabbi and talmudist. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day. As his name indicates, he was born in Seville in southern Spain shortly after its reconquest by the Christians from the Moslems. Though he was a leading student of the Ramban and the generation succeeding him, he he also devoted significant time and energy to the study of Rambam's Moreh Nevuchim and other philosophical works. He served as rabbi of Sarragossa, where he establish a Beit Din and yeshiva.

The Tosafists (12th - 13th centuries) are primarily noted for the commentary on the Talmud. Da'at Zekeinim is a Torah commentary that generally provides "peshat" or "straighforward" interpretations of the text.
column11: בעלי התוספות (המאות ה-12 וה-13) ידועים בעיקר בזכות פירושם לתלמוד. דעת זקנים הוא פירוש לתורה שבדרך כלל מספק פירושי "פשט" לכתוב.

column2: Raavad, Avraham ben David of Posquières
column10: Rabbi Avraham ben David of Posquieres (Ra'avad) was a Provencal rabbi, talmudist, and mystic. His best-know work are his extensive critical comments on Rambam Mishneh Torah which are published alongside the Rambam's text in almost every version. He also engaged in written disputes via commentary with his younger contemporary, R. Zerachia Halevi, in defence of the Rif's Halachot. He wrote talmudic commentaries which are quoted extensively by a number of Rishonim. It was from his circle whence the Kabbalah emerged in the 12th century, and the early prominent kabbalists cite his activity as central to that emergence.
column19: Moses ben Joseph, Meshullam of Lunel

column10: Rabbi Yitzchak Alfasi, better known as the Rif, was a North African rabbI, talmudist, and halachic decisor. His best-know work was Hilchot HaRif, a digest of Talmudic discussions, followed by the Rif's decisions, which became widely authoritative and formed one of the pillars of the Shulchan Aruch. He is sometimes considered the last of the Gaonim, due to the great authority and reverence he enjoyed. His teacher was Rabbenu Chananel and among his students were R. Yehudah Halevi and R. Yosef (the Ri) Migash.

Rabbi Natan ben Yechiel of Rome was an Italian rabbi and lexicographer. His central work, the Aruch, was the first Talmudic dictionary, and achieved a wide circulation soon after publication. He worked as a peddler of linen, until the opportunity came to devote himself entirely to Torah study. He travelled abroad to study with luminaries in Sicily and Narbonne, eventually returning to serve as head of the yeshiva in Rome.
column19: Mazliach ibn al-Basaq, Moses ha-Darshan, Moses Kalfo

column10: Rabbi Shmuel Eidels (Maharsha) was a Polish rabbi and talmudist whose novellae on both halachic and aggadic passages are found in almost every edition of the Talmud. He was a child prodigy and initially rejected many marriage offers to devote himself entirel to Torah study. After marrying, he moved to Pozen and established a yeshiva, which was supported for twenty years by his mother-in-law, Eidel. In gratitute of her unstinting support, he adopted her name as his surname. He was an active participant in the Council of Four Lands.
column25: Son In law Moses ben Isaac Bonems

column10: Rabbi Chayyim Ibn Atar (d. 1743) was a Moroccan Torah commentator, halakhic decisor, and kabbalist. Or HaChayyim is a Torah commentary which often incorporates Kabbalistic teachings to elucidate the verses of the Bible.
column11: רבי חיים בן עטר (נפטר 1743) היה פרשן תורה מרוקאי, פוסק הלכה ומקובל. "אור החיים" הוא פירוש לתורה שלעתים קרובות משלב רעיונות קבליים כדי להסביר את הפסוקים בתנ"ך.

column10: Rabbi Meir ben Baruch of Rothenburg was a German talmudist and liturgist, one of the important Tosafists. He also authored many responsa. His practices carefully noted by his many disciples, had an unparalleled formative impact on subsequent Ashkenazic practice. Toward the end of his life, he was captured and held by German Christian  authorities. His disciples raised the huge ranson demanded, but he refused to allow its payment, aware of the precendent it could set. He died in prison and was ransomed years later for Jewish burial. His most prominent disciple, R. Asher ben Yechiel (the Rosh), fled to Spain in the wake of what befell his teacher.
column19: Isaac ben Moses of Vienna,  Yehiel of Paris, Samuel ben Solomon of Falaise, Samuel of Evreux

column10: Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel was a prominent talmudist, halachist and tosafist. He was born, lived and taught in Germany, fleeing with his family to Spain after the imprisonment and death of his teacher, the Maharam of Rothenberg. He served as as leading authority in Spain alongside the Rashba. His halakhic authority, due to the tremendous impact of his work, Hilchot HaRosh, was such that he was one of three sages selected by R. Yosef Karo to serve as the "Beit Din" for his Beit Yosef and Shulchan Aruch.

Rabbi Jacob ben Asher was born in Germany (some place the year as 1250, some 1269) but lived most of his life in Spain. He is most famous for having composed the great law code, Arba'ah Turim. Ba'al HaTurim HaShalem is a commentary on the Torah which draws on the works of other commentators, particularly that of Ramban.
column11: רבי יעקב בן אשר (נפטר 1340) נולד בגרמניה אך חי את רוב חייו בספרד. חיבורו המפורסם ביותר הוא ספרי ההלכה - ה"ארבעה טורים". בעל הטורים השלם הוא פירוש על התורה שמסתמך על פירושם של פרשנים אחרים, במיוחד הרמב"ן.

column10: Shabbetai Bass was a Polish printer, publisher, bibliographer and author of Siftei Chakhamim, the most widely used supercommentary on Rashi's commentary to the Chumash and Megillot. His surname stems from his position as bass singer in the choir of the Altneuschul of Prague, where he went to learn Torah after his parent's martyrdom. He settled in Amsterdam in 1579 after extensive travel's, where he learned the printer's craft. He subsequently settled in Breslau where he set up a successful publishing/printing establishment. He was a ground-breaking bibliographer whose classification system was unprecedented at his time. In his old-age, he was falsely charged with priting works blasphemous against Christianity, though eventually acquitted, spent time in prison. His last years were devoted to revising his bibliographical work, but he died before he could complete the revision.
Rabbi Shlomo HaKohen ben Eliezer of Lissa was a German/Polish rabbi, shochet, and biblical commentator. He wrote a supercommentary on the commentary of Abraham ibn Ezra on the Chumash.

Abarbanel was a Bible commentator, philosopher, and statesman. Born in Portugal, he lived much of his life in Spain, and died in Venice. Abarbanel's commentary always begins with a number of questions about the text at hand, which he answers over the course of his exegesis.
column11: אברבנאל (נפטר 1508) היה פרשן תנ"ך, פילוסוף ומדינאי. הוא נולד בפורטוגל, חי את רוב חייו בספרד ונפטר בוונציה. פירושו של אברבנאל תמיד מתחיל בכמה שאלות על הכתוב של אותו פרק, ועליהן הוא עונה במהלך פירושו.

column2: Meir Levush ben Yehiel Michael Wieser
column4: מאיר ליבוש בן יחיאל מיכל וייזר
column10: Rabbi Meir Leivush Weisser, known as Malbim, was a scholar, orator, and Torah commentator who traveled and lived in a number of locations in Eastern Europe. Malbim is a Torah commentary which attempts to defend the traditional approach to Torah study against the innovations of the Reform movement, and to show that the Oral Law is deeply rooted in the text of the Bible.
column11: רבי מאיר ליבוש וייזר, הידוע בכינויו המלבי"ם, היה מלומד, דורש ופרשן תורה שגר בכמה מקומות במזרח אירופה. המלבי"ם הוא פירוש לתורה שמנסה להגן על הגישה המסורתית ללימוד תורה מול החידושים של התנועה הרפורמית, ולהראות שהתורה שבעל פה נטועה עמוק בכתוב בתנ"ך.

column2: David Ben Yosef Kamhi, David Ben Yosef Kimhi
column10: Rabbi David Kimchi was a French Torah scholar, philosopher, and Hebrew grammarian. Radak's Bible commentary frequently focuses on grammatical and etymological issues within the verses.
column11: רבי דוד קמחי (נפטר 1235) חי בצרפת היה ותלמיד חכם, פילוסוף ומדקדק. פירושו של רד"ק מתמקד הרבה בעניינים דקדוקיים ואטימולוגיים בתוך הפסוקים.

column10: Rabbi Meir Simchah of Dvinsk was a Lithuanian rabbi who wrote on issues of Jewish law and Talmud, in addition to his Torah commentary. Meshekh Chochmah is a philosophically-inclined commentary which if often noted for its originality and depth.
column11: רבי מאיר שמחה מדווינסק (נפטר 1926) חי בליטא וכתב דברים הנודעים לענייני הלכה ותלמוד, נוסף על פירושו לתורה. משך חכמה הוא פירוש עם נטייה פילוסופית שמצוין לעתים קרובות כבעל מקוריות ועומק יוצאים מן הכלל.

column10: Rabbi Chizkiah ben Manoach lived in the thirteenth century, probably in France. The details of his biography are unknown. Chizkuni is a commentary on the Torah which quotes earlier commentators, particularly Rashi, and further explains these comments, as well as the verses they elucidate.
column11: רבי חזקיה בן מנוח חי במאה ה-13, כנראה בצרפת. פרטי הביוגרפיה שלו אינם ידועים. החזקוני הוא פירוש לתורה שמצטט פרשנים קדומים יותר, בעיקר את רש"י, ומסביר פירושים אלה ואת הפסוקים שאותם הם מבהירים.

column10: Rabbi Levi ben Gershon was a French philosopher, mathemetician, astrologer, and Torah commentator. Ralbag's Torah commentary includes an explanation of the words of each section, a commentary on the meaning, and an exploration of the deeper meanings and morals that emerge. There is debate about the year of his death - some place it at 1344, some 1370.
column11: רבי לוי בן גרשון (נפטר 1344) היה פילוסוף צרפתי, מתמטיקאי, אסטרולוג ופרשן תורה. פירוש רלב"ג לתורה כולל הסבר על המילים בכל פסוק, פירוש המשמעות שבו, וחקר המשמעויות העמוקות יותר והמסרים העולים מהכתוב.

column10: Moshe Alshikh (d. 1593) was a rabbi and orator who was born in the Ottoman Empire and lived in Safed. Moshe Alshikh's Torah commentary, called Torat Moshe, is based on the lectures he gave on the weekly Torah portion. It is a homiletical commentary which extracts moral lessons from the verses.
column11: משה אלשייך (נפטר 1593) היה רב ודרשן שנולד באימפריה העות'מנית וחי בצפת. פירושו של רבי משה אלשייך, המכונה "תורת משה", מבוסס על הדרשות השבועויות שלו על פרשת השבוע. פירושו הוא בסגנון אגדה והוא מוציא מתוך הכתוב עניינים במוסר.

column2: Bahya ibn Pequdah, Bachya ibn Pekuda
column10: Rabbi Bachya ben Asher was a Spanish Torah scholar and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary.
column11: רבנו בחיי בן אשר (נפטר בסביבות 1340) חי בספרד והיה תלמיד חכם ודרשן, והוא ידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו לתורה.

column10: Rabbi Vidal of Tolosa (d. 1360) was a French rabbi and halachic author. Very little is known of the details of his life. He is better knows as the Maggid Mishneh, after his great work, a comprehensive commentary on Rambam's Mishneh Torah, of which only a part has come down to us. In his work, he seeks the sources for the Rambam's rulings and defends him against criticisms such as those of the Ra'avad.

Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch was a German scholar, writer and activist. He pioneered a neo-Orthodox movement that championed engagement with Western culture while also maintaining strict observance of Jewish law. Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch's Torah commentary carefully analyzes the language of the Torah and often explains the deeper meanings of commandments.
column11: הרב שמשון רפאל הירש (נפטר 1888) היה מלומד גרמני, סופר ופעיל פוליטית. היה החלוץ של תנועה נאו-אורתודוקסית שדגלה בשילוב העולם המערבי עם שמירת מצוות אדוקה. פירושו של הרש"ר הירש מנתח בזהירות את הלשון בתורה ומסביר את המשמעויות העמוקות שבמצוות.

column10: Rabbi Barukh HaLevi Epstein (d.1941) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, who is best known for his Torah commentary, the Torah Temimah. Torah Temimah is a commentary on the Torah which cites all Talmudic or Midrashic references to a particular verse and provides explanations.
column11: הרב ברוך הלוי אפשטיין (נפטר 1941) היה רב ומלומד ליטאי שידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו לתורה, "תורה תמימה". תורה תמימה היא פירוש על התורה שמביא את כל האזכורים מהתלמוד או ממדרשים לפסוק מסוים ומספק הסברים.

column10: Netsiv (d. 1893) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, and was the head of the prominent Volozhin Yeshiva. HaEmek Davar is a Torah commentary, based on the Netsiv's classes on the weekly Torah portion, which explores the deeper meaning of each verse, and shows how Rabbinic law is closely connected to the Biblical text.
column11: הנצי"ב (נפטר 1893) היה רב ומלומד ליטאי וראש ישיבת וולוז'ין. העמק דבר הוא פירוש לתורה שמבוסס על שיעורי הנצי"ב על פרשת השבוע, והוא מתחקה אחר המשמעות העמוקה של כל פסוק ומראה כיצד הלכה רבנית קשורה לכתוב בתנ"ך.
column18: Yitzchok of Volozhin, Yechiel Michel Epstein

column10: Rabbi Yitschak ben Moshe Arama was a Spanish Talmudist and philosophically-oriented exegete. Akeidat Yitschak is a Torah commentary which is philosophical and also imparts moral and ethical teachings.
column11: הרב יצחק בן משה עראמה (נפטר 1494) חי בספרד והיה בעל גמרא ופרשן בעל נטייה פילוסופית. "עקידת יצחק" היא פירוש לתורה בעל אופי פילוסופי ורווי שיעורים במוסר ובאתיקה.

column10: Rabbi Yosef Dov Soloveitchik was a Lithuanian scholar and served as rabbi in a number of communities, culminating in his appointment as rabbi of Brisk. Beit HaLevi is a Torah commentary which ilustrates the connections between Midrash and rabbinic law, and the text of the Torah.
column11: הרב יוסף דוב סולובייצ'יק (נפטר 1892) היה תלמיד חכם ליטאי שכיהן כרב בכמה קהילות עד שמונה להיות הרב של בריסק. "בית הלוי" הוא פירוש לתורה שקושר בין מדרש להלכה ולכתוב בתורה.

column3: העשיל מקראקא, אברהם יהושע העשל מקראקא
column10: Rabbi Abraham Joshua ben Jacob Heschel was a Lithuanian scholar and teacher, and later in his life became the head of the yeshiva in Cracow. Chanukkat HaTorah is a commentary on the Torah which gathers earlier rabbinic sayings and uses them to answer questions about each verse.
column11: הרב אברהם יהושע בן יעקב השל (נפטר 1664) היה תלמיד חכם ומורה ליטאי, ובהמשך חייו הפך לראש הישיבה בקרקוב. "חנוכת התורה" היא פירוש לתורה שאוסף אמרות רבניות קדומות ומשתמש בהן כדי לענות על שאלות מכל פסוק.
column25: Brother in law, Zechariah Mendel ben Aryeh Leib,  Samuel ben Uri Shraga Phoebus, Yehezkiah Joshua Feivel Teomim

column10: Rabbi Menachem ben Binyamin Recanati was an Italian kabbalist and halakhic decisor. Recanati's Torah commentary draws upon kabbalistic sources to explain the verses of the Torah.
column11: הרב מנחם בן בנימין רקנטי היה מקובל ופוסק הלכה איטלקי. הפירוש של רקנטי לתורה משתמש במקורות קבליים כדי להסביר את הפסוקים בתורה.

column10: Samuel David Luzzatto also known as the Shadal, was an Italian scholar, poet, philosopher and Biblical commentator. With the help of Rabbi Isaac Samuel Reggio, he was appointed a professor at the rabbinical college of Padua, where he taught Bible, philology, philosophy, and Jewish history until his death. Though religiously observant and a defender of tradition, he applied critical scholarship to his Hebrew commentary of the Torah. He was a prolific writer, contributing to Hebrew and Jewish journals, and corresponding in Hebrew, Italian, French and German with the major rabbis and scholars of his day. Some of this correspondence was later collected by his son and published as the Iggerot Shadal.

column2: Aderet Eliyahu, HaGra, Elijah ben Shlomo Zalman from Vilna
column10: Rabbi Eliyahu ben Shlomo Zalman (1720-1797), also known as the Vilna Gaon, was a talmudist and the greatest Torah authority of his generation. He had a photographic memory; according to legend he memorized the Pentateuch by the age of three. By the age of 20 he was already resolving complicated legal issues that confounded other rabbis. He wrote copious commentaries on virtually all Jewish texts, including corrective notes on the Talmud. He also authored books on grammar and mathematics and encouraged his students to learn the secular sciences.  He may be best remembered as one of the leaders of the "Misnagdim," the opponents of the newly emergent Hasidic movement. He declared that the Hasidic belief in miracles and visions were lies and delusions and advocated a more rational approach to Torah observance that emphasized the traditional obligations of Torah study and fulfillment of the commandments.

Rabbi Yeshayanu Levi Horovitz was Polish rabbi and kabbalist. He was the most illustrious member of the distinguished Horovitz family, descended from Rabbi Zerachia Halevi of Gerona, which spans hundreds of years and counts many distinguished rabbi and intellectuals amongst its members. He was born in Prague and studied under his highly learned father and the greatest rabbis of his day.  After serving in various communities, he returned to the city of his birth as chief rabbi. In 1621 he moved to the Land of Israel, where he was appointed chief rabbi of the Ashkenazic community in Jerusalem.  He moved to Tzfat and Teveriah shortly after being ransomed from captivity in 1625, where he further immersed himself in kabbalist study. His great work, Shnei Luchot HaBrit, ,published by his son, is almost unparalleled in its impact on Ashkenazic Jewish life, playing an enormous role in spreading and popularizing Kabbalistic ideas. He had a huge impact upon the Chassidic movement, which sprang up soon after his passing, through his teachings and his descendants, some of whom were great Chassidic leaders.
column19: Avraham ben Shabtai Sheftel Horowitz, Meir Lublin, Joshua Falk

column10: Rabbi Chananel ben Chushiel (Rabbeinu Chananel) was a North African rabbi and talmudist. He is considered one of the first Rishonim and studied under the last of the Geonim.  His family was from Italy and migrated to Kairowan, where he attained great renown. He served as rosh yeshiva in Kairowan after the passing of his father. He maintained a lively correspondence with the heads of the great yeshivot in Babylonian. He was also successful in business and attained great wealth. His commentary on the Talmud is the earliest comprehensive commentary.

Rabbi Shlomo Luria (Maharshal) was a Polish rabbi, halakhic decisor and talmudist. His prominent family claimed descent from Rashi. He served as rosh yeshiva of the famed yeshiva in Lublin, Poland. He maintained a spirited correspondence with the Rama, to whom he was related. They disagreed pointedly on the importance of philosophy and grammar. He is known for his independence in Torah matters and his strident criticism of the approach of his contemporary scholars to Talmudic commentary. Though his great halachic work, Yam shel Shlomo was overshadowed by the contemporary Shulchan Aruch, it remains a mainstay of Talmudic learning to this day.
Rabbi Avraham Saba was a Spanish teacher and exegete who spent much of his life fleeing persecution. Tseror HaMor is a commentary on the Torah which incorporates mystical explanations from the Zohar.
column11: רבי אברהם סבע (נפטר 1508) היה מורה ופרשן ספרדי שנאלץ רוב חייו לברוח מרדיפות. "צרור המור" הוא פירוש על התורה שמשלב בתוכו הסברים מיסטיים מהזוהר.

column10: Yonatan Eybeschutz was a German rabbi, talmudist, halachic decisor, kabbalist and homilist, writing prolifically in all these fields. He was a child prodigy and his personaliity created a great impression upon peope from early on. He spend many years as a rosh yeshiva and dayyan in Prague, but he was never appointed as chief rabbi of city due to suspicions that he was secretly a Sabbatean. While he strenuously denied the allegations, the suspicions continued, espoused especially by Rabbi Yaakov Emden, who deciphered cryptic names in amulets prepared by Rabbi Yonatan as definitively Sabbatean in nature, and found connections between his writings and those of an acquaintance. A contemporary rabbincal tribunal exonerated him of the allegations, and his works are widely studied to this day. He was a preacher of great force and eloquence and his collected homilies are amongst the most famous.
Rabbi Mecklenberg was a German rabbi and Torah scholar. HaKetav VeHakabbalah is a Torah commentary designed to demonstrate the close connections between Rabbinic law and the Biblical text.
column11: הרב יעקב צבי מקלנבורג (נפטר 1865) היה רב ותלמיד חכם גרמני. "הכתב והקבלה" הוא פירוש לתורה שמטרתו להראות את הקשר הקרוב בין הלכה לטקסט התנ"כי.

column10: Rabbi Yitschak ben Asher Halevi was an early Tosafist who lived in Speyer and was a student of Rashi, the great Talmud and Torah commentator. Riv"a's Torah commentary is preserved in texts from other Tosafists (Talmud commentators) of his time.
column11: הרב יצחק בן אשר הלוי (המאה ה-11) היה בעל תוספות מוקדם שחי בשפייר והיה תלמיד של רש"י, פרשן התורה והתלמוד הידוע. פירוש הריב"א לתורה נשמר בכתבים מבעלי תוספות אחרעם בדורו.

column10: Rabbi Hayyim Yosef David Azulai was a scholar and a prolific writer and publisher. He was born in Jerusalem, and spent much of his life traveling throughout the Jewish communities of Europe.
column11: הרב חיים יוסף דוד אזולאי (נפטר 1806) היה תלמיד חכם, סופר ומוציא לאור. הוא נולד בירושלים ובילה את רוב חייו בנסיעות לקהילות שונות באירופה.

column2: R. Velvel Soloveitchik, Yizhak Zev Halevi Soloveitchik
column10: Rabbi Yitschak Zev HaLevi Soloveitchik, also known as the "Brisker Rav," was the head of the Brisk Yeshiva in Jerusalem. The Gri"z (which stands for Gaon Rabbi Yitschak Zev) is famous for his conceptual approach to all texts, including in his Torah commentary.
column11: הרב יצחק זאב הלוי סולובייצ'יק (נפטר 1959), הידוע גם בכינויו "הרב מבריסק", היה ראש ישיבת בריסק בירושלים. הגרי"ז (ראשי תיבות של הגאון רבי יצחק זאב) ידוע בזכות גישתו הקונספטואלית לכל הטקסטים, כולל פירושו לתורה.

column10: Rabbi Yosef ben Meir Teomim was a Galician halakhist and teacher. He is best known for his legal commentaries on the Shulkhan Arukh, the great sixteenth-century law code.
column11: הרב יוסף בן מאיר תאומים (נפטר 1792) חי בגליציה והיה איש הלכה ומורה. הוא ידוע בזכות הפירושים ההלכתיים שלו על השולחן ערוך, ספר ההלכה החשוב מהמאה ה-16.

column10: Rabbi Yitschak Karo was a Spanish teacher, halakhic decisor, and physician. Toldot Yitschak is a commentary on the five books of the Torah
column11: רבי יצחק קארו (נפטר 1535) חי בספרד והיה מורה, פוסק הלכה ורופא. "תולדות יצחק" הוא פירוש על חמישה חומשי תורה.

column2: David ben Josef ben David Abudarham
column4: דוד בן יוסף בן דוד אבודרהם
column10: Rabbi David ben Yosef Abudraham (mid. 14th century) was a Spanish rabbi and commentator on Jewish liturgy. His best-work is Sefer Abudraham, one of the earliest and most widely accepted commentary and explanatiion on Jewish liturgy. He was closely connect to the Rosh and his son, R. Yaakov Ba'al HaTurim.

Rabbi Benno Jacob was a Reform German rabbi who also had an academic degree in Semitics. Rabbi Benno Jacob's Torah commentary explains each verse in depth in order to show the internal logic of the Torah and to disprove the Documentary Hypothesis.
column11: הרב בנו יעקב (נפטר 1945) היה רב גרמני רפורמי בעל תואר אקדמי בשפות השמיות. פירושו לתורה מסביר כל פסוק לעומק כדי להראות את ההיגיון הפנימי של התורה ולסתור את תורת התעודות.

column10: Rabbi Chayyim Paltiel was a 13th century French Torah commentator.
column11: רבי חיים פלטיאל היה פרשן תורה צרפתי מהמאה ה-13.

column10: Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura was an Italian scholar who was most famous for his Mishnah commentary. Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura's Torah commentary elucidates Rashi's comments on the Torah.
column11: רבי עובדיה מברטנורא (נפטר בסביבות 1515) היה תלמיד חכם איטלקי שידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו למשנה. פירושו של רבי עובדיה מברטנורא מבהיר את פירושו של רש"י על התורה.

column10: Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi was a talmudist and halakhic decisor who served as Chief Rabbi of the Ottoman Empire. Sefer HaMizrachi is a supercommentary on Rashi's Torah commentary, which explains Rashi's sources and elucidates his comments.
column11: הרב אליהו מזרחי (נפטר בסביבות 1525) היה בעל גמרא ופוסק הלכה שכיהן כרב הראשי של האימפריה העות'מנית. ספר המזרחי הוא פירוש על פירושו של רש"י לתורה. הוא מסביר את המקורות של רש"י ומבהיר את הפירושים שלו.

column10: Rabbi Yehuda Loew ben Bezalel, the Maharal of Prague, was a Bohemian rabbi, talmudist, mystically inclined philosopher and community leader whose personality wriitings left an indelible impression on both his immediate and subsequent generations of Ashekenazic Jewry.  His numerous philosophical works became cornerstones of Jewish thought, and had a profound influence on Chassidic teaching and some of the most prominent thinkers of modern Orthodoxy, including Rav Kook.  He also wrote halachic works, including a commentary on the Arba'ah Turim.  He had a close relationship with the famous astronomer Tycho Brahe. Amongst his students were R. Yom Tov Lipmann Heller (Tosafot Yom Tov) and the historian R David Ganz (Tzemach David). He is famously associated with the Golem of Prague in popular literature from centuries later.

Rabbi David Altshul was an 18th century Torah commentator. Metsudat David is a commentary on Prophets and Writings that is designed to help the reader understand the meaning of the text. Metsudat Tsion is essentially a dictionary for difficult words in the Bible; the words are listed and translated.
column11: הרב דוד אלטשול היה פרשן תורה שחי במאה ה-18. "מצודת דוד" הוא פירוש על הנביאים והכתובים שמטרתו לעזור ללומד להבין את משמעות הכתוב. "מצודת ציון" הוא למעשה מילון למילים קשות בתנ"ך; המילים רשומות ומתורגמות.

column10: Rabbi Yedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Nortsi was an Italian rabbi and Biblical scholar. Minchat Shai is a critical commentary of the Bible which presents all of the variant readings from within Rabbinic literature.
column11: הרב ידידיה שלמה בן אברהם נורצי (נפטר 1626) היה רב איטלקי וחוקר מקרא. מנחת שי הוא פרשנות ביקורתית על התנ"ך המציגה את כל קריאות הגרסה מתוך ספרות חז"ל.

column10: Onkelos, according to tradition, was a Roman convert to Judaism who lived in the first or second century.  He translated Tanach into Aramaic, the spoken language of the day. Some identify Onkelos with a convert named Aquilas who translated the Tanach into Greek. According to tradition he was counselled by his uncle, the emperor, to succeed by buying low and selling high. He later explained his conversion to his incensed uncle by repeating to him his own advice of years earlier. Onkelos' translation became the standard Aramaic translation, used daily by Jews world-wide long after Aramaic ceased being a living language for most Jews.

Rabbi Yoel Sirkes (d. 1640) was a Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudic annotator. His best-know work, Bait Chadash, is one of the basic commentaries (together with R Yosef Karo's Beit Yosef) on R. Yaakov ben Asher's halachic code, the Arba'ah Turim. Hagahot Habach are his indispensible glosses on the text of the Talmud. The Taz was his son-in-law.

Rabbi Shabbatai Hakohen was a Lithuanian/Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudist. His best-know work, Siftei Kohen, is one of the basic commentaries on the Shulchan Aruch (on the sections Yoreh Deah and Choshen Mishpat). His rulings were widely accepted by Ashkenazic Jewry as authoritative. He wrote critical commentaries on the Turei Zahav, the other great commentary on the Shulchan Aruch.

Rabbi David Halevi Segal was a Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudist. His best-known work, Turei Zahav, is one of the basic commentaries on the Shulchan Aruch (on all four sections, most prominently on Yoreh Deah and Orach Chayyim). He responded to the Shach's critiques of his expositions and decisions in a separate work. and also authored Divrei David, a supercommentary on Rashi's Torah commentary. The Bach was his father-in-law

Rabbi Yaakov Emden was a German rabbi, talmudist and polemecist. He is most well-known for his publically promoted and literarily defended identification of Rabbi Yonatan Eibeschutz as a hidden Sabbatean. He published many works, amongst which is a highly regarded and republished siddur with extensive commentary, and a collection of responsa, She'ilat Ya'avetz. His father was the Chacham Tzvi.

Rabbi Yom-Tov Lipmann Heller, was a Bohemian rabbi and talmudist. His best-known work, Tosafot Yom Tov, is one of the basic commentaries on the Mishnah. He also wrote Ma'adanei Yom Tov, an important commentary on Piskei HaRosh of Rabbi Asher ben Yechiel. He studied under the Maharal of Prague, and served as rabbi of Vienna and Prague. Many prominent rabbis of subsequent generations are his descendants.

Martin Buber was a Jewish scholar and philosopher best known for his existentialist work I and Thou (Ich und Du) He was born in an Orthodox home in Vienna and raised in Lvov, but later returned to Vienna to study modern philosphy. He was a scholar, translator and explicator of Hasidic lore, which he compiled in Tales of the Hasidim. He was an ardent Zionist, settling in Jerusalem in 1938, where he became a professor at the Hebrew University.

Solomon (or Salomon) Buber was a scholar and editor of Hebrew works, particularly known for his original research and prolific explication of Midrashic literature. He wrote elaborate and exhaustive commentaries of Midrashic works including Pesikhta de-Rab Kahana, Midrash Abkir, Midrash Tanchuma, Midrash Tehillim, Midrash Shmuel and Midrash Mishle. He was also the primary teacher of his grandson, Martin Buber, who lived with him from the age of three.

Rabbi Eliyahu David Rabinowitz Teomim (d. 1905. known by his acronym, Aderet), was a Lithuanian rabbi and talmudist who served, toward the end of his life, as leader of the Ashkenazic community in Jerusalem.  He wrote many works, filled with original insights, in all areas of Torah. Rabbi Avraham Yitzchak Hakohen Kook was his son-in-law.

Rabbi Yochanan Treves (d. 1439) was a French rabbi and talmudist. As chielf rabbi of France, he was involved in a bitter dispute with R. Yitzchak ben Abba Mari regarding the right to ordain French rabbis. Upon the expulsion of Jews from France in he settled in Italy.  Many of his rulings are quoted in the authoritative halachic compendium, Sha'arei Dura.

Rabbi Eliyahu Ben Harush was a Moroccan rabbi. He was known for his great humility and constant devotion to Torah study. His sermons and poetry were also highly admired. He wrote a commentary on the Chumash and the Haggadah.

column2: Yaakov ben Yaakov Moshe Lorberbaum of Lissa, Ba'al HaChavat Da'at, Ba'al HaNesivot, the Rav of Lissa
column10: Rabbi Yaakov Lorberbaum (d. 1832), was a Polish rabbi, talmudist and halachic decisor. His best-known works, Chavot Da'at, on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh De'ah and Netivot Mishpat, on Shulchan Aruch Choshen Mishpat have had a formative impact on classic Torah study to the present day. He was a great-grandson of the Chacham Tzvi.
column25: Relative of Jacob Emden and Joseph Teomim

column10: Rabbi Yedidiah Tiah Weil was a German rabbi. He received his early instruction from his father. the Korban Netan'el.. In 1744 he married Gitel, daughter of Jacob Eger, a well-to-do resident of Prague; but the expulsion of the Jews from Prague led him to Metz in 1745, where he remained until 1748, continuing his studies under Jonathan Eybeschütz.  In 1770 he succeeded his father as rabbi of Carlsruhe. . His will shows him to have been a man of great piety and knowlegeable in Kabbalah.

Rabbi Naftali Hertz Ginzburg was a Polish rabbi who came from an illustrious family that produced nine generations of Rabbis and was widely respected for his Torah knowledge.  He had daughters, but, to his dismay, no sons.

column2: Yismach Yisrael, Yerachmiel Israel Yitzchak Dancyger
column10: Rabbi Yirachmiel Yisrael Danziger (d. 1910) was the second Rebbe of the Alexander Chassidic dynasty in Poland. His work, Yismach Yisrael, focuses on practical piety and is widely learned in other Chassidic circles as well. He emphasized ecstatic prayer in worship.

Rabbi Avraham Yitzchak Hakohen Kook (d. 1935) was a towering Torah personality and tremendously influential leader in Lithuania and the Land of Israel. A master of almost every facet of Jewish literature, he wrote halachic and aggadic works, as well as philosophical and mystical tracts, responsa and commentaries. His voluminous correspondence covers every imaginable topic. He served as chief rabbi of Yaffo and as the first modern chief rabbi of the entire Jewish community of the Land of Israel.

Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzatto (d. 1707) was an Italian rabbi, kabbalist and philosopher who also wrote dramatic worrks and literary criticism. Gifted with an almost photographic memory, he wrote many works, some which became standards of kabbalah and ethics. He was suspected of Sabbateanism but exonerated by his teachers and colleagues, with a warning to cease engaging in speculative kabbalistic writing. Toward the end of his life, he moved to the Land of Israel.

column2: Joseph ben Ephraim Karo, Maran, Hamehaber
column10: Rabbi Yosef Karo (d. 1575), expelled from Spain as a child, was a rabbi, talmudist, mystic and a pre-emiment halakhic codifier. His best-known work, the Shulchan Aruch, was accepted in his lifetime and subsequently as the definitive statement of Jewish legal and religious practice. He also wrote basic commentaries on the Mishneh Torah and the Arba'ah Turim (the latter forming the basis from which the Shulchan Aruch was distilled). He was also a mystic who received heavenly revelations. Some of these were set down in writing and formed the impetus to come to the Land of Israel. There, he lived in Tsfat, where he took a central role in the attempt by his teacher, R.Yaakov Berav, to revive traditional rabbinic Semichah.
column18: Isaac Saba, Hayyim Albalag,  Zechariah Sechsel

column10: Rabbi Moshe Cordovero, also referred to as RaMak, (d. 1570) was a leading Kabbalist who lived and taught in Tsfat, in Land of Israel. His best-known work, Pardes Rimmonim, is a systematation of various school of Kabbalistic thought. He many highly influential works, included a defense of Kabbalah, an highly-regarded ethical work based of Kabbalistic thought, and a comprehsive commentary on the Zohar. He had many disciples and was considered the premier Kabbalistic authority until superceded by R. Yitzchak Luria shortly after his death.

column2: Nachman, Nahman of Breslov, Nachman of Bratzlav, Rebbe Nachman, Rebbe Nahman
column10: Rabbi Nachman of Breslov was one of the most creative Chassidic masters, whose thought and teachings continue to resonate within wide circles far beyond his immediate followers. He was a great-grandson of the founder of Chassidut, R. Yisrael Ba'al Shem Tov, and a grandson of another early Chassidic master, R. Nachman of Horodenka. Among his many works are a profound presentation of his Chassidic and mystical teaching, Likkutei Moharan, and a compilation of his intricate and powerfully evocative stories, Sippurei Ma'asiyot.  Another work relates the events of his transformatic journey to and trom the Land of Israel. He was severely criticized by certain contemporary Chassidic masters, but defended by the leading Chassidic master, R. Levi Yitzchak of Berdichev. He moved to Uman less than a year before he passed away from tuberculosis, and his grave there is a pilgrimage site for thousands to this day.

Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liady (d. 1812), was the founder of Lubavitch (Chabad) Chassidut. He was a leading disciple of the Maggid of Mezeritch, who send his to Lithuania to spread Chassidut and assigned him the task of composed a Shulchan Aruch which reflected Chassidic practices (Shulchan Aruch HaRav). His best-know work is the vastly influential Likkutei Amarim, better known as Tanya.  He wrote other works of Chassidut and Kabbalah, including Torah Or and Likkutei Torah. In the dispute between Chassidim and Mitnagdim, he was falsely accused of fomenting rebellion against the Tsar and imprisoned. His release from prision, considered to portend profound developments, is celebrated by Chabad Chassidim to this day. He was succeeded as Rebbe by his son, R. Dov Baer.
column25: Greatgrand son of Maharal of Prague

column4: ר' צדקיה בן ר' אברהם הרופא הענוים
column10: Zedekiah ben Abraham Anav (d. 1280), was an Italian Rabbi and halachist. His work, Shibbolei Haleket, was a halachic compendium which was referenced extensively by subsequent halachists.
column19: Jacob of Wurzburg, Abigdor Cohen of Vienna

column10: Betsalel ben Avraham Ashkenazi, was an Egyptian rabbi and talmudist. His best-known work is Shittah Mekubetzet, a highly influential compendium of earlier commentaries on a number of key Talmudic tractates. He was a student of the Rabbi David ben Solomon ibn Abi Zimra (the Radbaz) and R. Yitzchak Luria was his student. Toward the end of his life, he travelled to the Land of Israel and served as chief rabbi in Jerusalem, resolving a serious dispute between subcommunities.
column19: David ben Solomon ibn Abi Zimra, Israel de Curial

column10: Rabbi Marcus Jastrow (1829 - 1903) was a Talmudic scholar and author of A Dictionary of the Targumim, Talmud Babli, Talmud Yerushalmi and Midrashic Literature, popularly known as "The Jastrow." He was also the rabbi of the Orthodox congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia from 1866 to 1892. Under his leadership, the congregation acquired an organ and was initially allowed to join the Reform movement. However, after the Reform Movement rallied around its radical "Pittsburgh Platform," he withdrew his congregation from the movement.

Rabbi Avraham Gombiner (Magen Avraham) was a Polish rabbi and halakhist whose rulings have had a decisive impact on Ashkenazic practice. After his parents were killed in the Chmielnicki massacres of 1648, he moved to Leszno. He served as rabbi in Kalish for many years, and his extreme humility prevented his great Torah learning from gaining him wider recognition. Only when the Shach visited the town and revealed his greatness did he assume a more senior rabbinic position. His great work, Magen Avraham on Shulchan Aruch Orech Chayyim was published posthumously, as he did not have the funds to publish it during his lifetime. He incorporated Polish customs and kabbalistic practices in his work, ofter derived from the Shelah..

Rabbi Moshe ben Yitzchak Yehudah Lima was a Polish/Lithuanian rabbi and halachist. He learned in Cracow and served as rabbi in Slonim before moving to Vilna and, at the end of his life, to Brisk. The Shach was a member of the beit din over which he presided. His work, Chelkat Mechokek, is one of the basic commentaries to Shulchan Aruch Even HaEzer.

Yosef Hayyim, also known as the Ben-Ish Chai, was the Chacham of the Jewish community of Baghdad. He was a preminent authority on halachah and a master kabbalist. His work the Ben Ish Chai, based on his classes on the weekly Torah reading, contain both kabbalistic insights into the Torah portion as well as practical laws for everyday life.
column19: Eliyahu Hayyim, David Hai b. Meir

column10: Rabbi Shlomo ben Joseph Ganzfried (1804-1886) was the author of the Kitzur Shulchan Aruch. He was rabbi of Brezevitz for many years before returning to his hometown of Ungvar (Austrian Empire/Ukraine) to serve as a dayan on the rabbinical court. In his role of community leader, Ganzfried came to believe that every Jew needed to know and understand Jewish law if Orthodoxy was to survive. To that end he composed the Kitzur Shulchan Aruch, which was widely popular and published both in Hebrew and in Yiddish.

Rabbi Israel Meir (HaKohen) Kagan, also known as the Chofetz Chaim, was a Lithuanian rabbi of the Musar movement. He was a יalakhist, posek and ethicist whose seminal works, the Chafetz Chaim and Shmirat HaLashon, have come to define the rules of proper speech. He also composed the Mishnah Berurah, a 6-volume commentary on the Orach Chaim section of the Shulchan Aruch. He was briefly the rabbi of Radun (Poland/Belarus), but resigned in order to found the Radun Yeshiva.

Judah ben Samuel of Regensburg (1150-1217), also known as Judah HeHasid, was a leader of the Chassidei Ashkenaz movement of mysticism and asceticism that flourished in the Rhineland in the 12th-13th centuries. He was born in Speyer to a family of kabbalists from Northern Italy. He founded a yeshiva in Regensburg which attracted many pupils,including Eleazar of Worms and Baruch ben Samuel of Mainz. Many liturgical works are tentatively attributed to Judah HeHasid, but he is most famous for his Sefer Hasidim, the foundational work of Chassidei Ashkenaz.

Rabbi Yechiel Michel Epstein (1829-1908) was also known as "the Aruch ha-Shulchan" after his יgreat halachic work by that name. He was a posek and the rabbi of Navardok, where he served for 34 years. He was married to the sister of Rabbi Naftali Zvi Yehudah Berlin (HaNatziv). He was known for his charitable works, particularly for his support of the Rebbi Meir Baal HaNeis charity fund which funded the Jews of Eretz Yisrael.
column25: Brother in law  Naftali Zvi Yehuda Berlin

column10: Rabbi Pinchas ben Yosef Halevi (14th century) was a Spanish rabbi. He was the brother of the famous Spanish talmudist, R. Aharon Halevy. Little is known of the details of his life. Some recent scholars have argued that he was the author of the anonymous work, Sefer haChinukh.

column2: Rabbi Sa'aidah Talmid HaGra, Sa'adya of Sklov
column4: רבי סעדיה תלמיד הגר"א, סעדיה משקלוב
column10: Rabbi Sa'adia was Polish/Lithuanian rabbi and prominent disciple of the Gra. He lived in his house, studied closely with him and served as amanuensis for a number of his works. He was sent by the Gra to publicize the latter's strident opposition to Chassidism. He came to the Land of Israell as one of the leaders of the second wave of the aliyah of the Gra's students. His work, Ma'aseh Rav, is the authoritative work on the Gra's rulings and customs relating to prayer.

Rabbi Yerucham ben Meshulam (d. 1350), better known as Rabbenu Yerucham, was a Spanish rabbi and halakhist. He was a student of the Rosh. His two works of halakhah, Sefer Meisharim and Sefer Toldot Adam v'Chavah, were published together and knows popularly as Rabbenu Yerucham. His rulings are quotes by R. Yosef Karo in his Beit Yosef.  Popular legend has led to few editions of Rabbenu Yerucham's works being printted, as those who commented on or reproduced the work were reputed to suffered.

Rabbi Yitzhak Yosef was born January 16, 1952 in Jerusalem. The son of Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, he is the Sephardi Chief Rabbi for the State of Israel (the Rishon Lezion), as well as the rosh yeshiva of Yeshivat Hazon Ovadia. He has written many foundational works for Sephardi Jews in Israel and the world, including Yalkut Yosef, a popular compendium of Jewish Law.

Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef  (September 24, 1920 – October 7, 2013) was the Sephardi Chief Rabbi of Israel from 1973 to 1983 and the greatest halachic authority for Sephardic Jewry in the modern era. He was born in Baghdad and made aliyah to Jerusalem with his family at the age of four. In 1950 he was appointed dayan to the rabbinical court of Petach Tikva, where he issued the first of the many bold and innovative rulings that marked his career. In 1984 he became a noteable figure in Israeli politics in founding the ultra-Orthodox Sephardi party Shas, serving as its spiritual leader until his death in 2013.

Rabbi Zechariah Mendel ben Aryeh Leib of Crakow was a Polish rabbi. He was the co-author, along with Yehudah ben Shimon Ashkenazi, of the Ba'er Hetev, a commentary on the Shulchan Aruch. In 1691 he became the Rosh Yeshiva of the yeshiva in Belz, Galicia.
column25: Brother in law Samuel ben Uri Shraga Phoebus, Yehezkiah Joshua Feivel Teomim, Heshel of Krakow

column10: Rabbi Yehuda Halevi was a Spanish poet and philosopher. He is considered to this day one of the greatest Hebrew poets of all generations, and his liturgical poetry appears in several prayer rites. He had a comprehisive education, including both secular and Torah subjects. Many are of the opinion that he was a direct student of the Rif. He also served as court physician of the king of Castille, and due to an enthusiastic patron, he was well-received in wide circles. He was especially close to Ibn Ezra, who quotes him a number of times in his commentaries.  His philosophical work Kuzari, is one of the great masterpieces of Jewish philosophy. Toward the end of his life, yearning for the Land of Israel, he travelled first to Egypt and, after an extended stay there, boarded a boat to the Land of Israel. Although legend attributes his demise to the hooves of a military mount in Jerusalem, there is no conclusive contemporary evidence as to what befell him and whether he actually reached the Land of Israel.

Rabbi Louis Ginzberg (November 28, 1873 - November 11, 1953), was a Talmudist and leading figure in the Conservative Movement. He was born in Kaunus, Vilna, to a religious family that traced it's lineage to the Gaon of Vilna. He came to America in 1899 and began teaching Talmud in 1902 at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, where he remained until his death. He is best known for his commentary on the Talmud Yerushalmi and for his 6-volume collection of aggadic literature, The Legends of the Jews.

column25: Brother Menahem ben Helbo, Son Joseph Kara

column10: Rabbi Yonah ben Yisrael Babad was a German rabbi and halachist. He lived in Regensburg during the 15th-16th centuries and was closely associated with Rabbi Yisrael Isserlein (Maharai). The influential work on Kashrut, Issur v'Heter HaAroch, has been attributed to him since the 17th century.

Rabbi Azriel of Gerona was a Spanish Kabbalist. He was the teacher of Ramban in Kabbalah. His Kabbalistic commentary on a number of passages of the Aggadah was one of the first works of Kabbalah to be made known publically. His brother, Rabbi Ezra, was also a well-known Kabbalist. His explanation and elucidation of the idea and details of the ten sefirot was one of the first explicit works of its kind.

Rabbi Yitzchak Sagi Nahor (Isaac the Blind) was a Provencal rabbi and Kabbalist. He was the son of the Ra'avad, and was active at the time that Sefer HaBahir was first emerging in public, so that in some circles he was considered its author. His students, Rabbi Azriel and Rabbi Ezra, were the teacher of the Ramban in Kabbalah.

Rabbi Yosef Giqatillah was a Spanish rabbi and Kabbalist. He was a student of Rabbi Avraham Abulafia and, like his teacher, focused on mystical combinations of letters, numbers and divine names. Unlike his teacher, he tried ot reconcile philosophy, of which he was quite knowledgeable, with Kabbalah. His work Sha'arei Orah, a dictionary of the Kabbalistic symbolism of the sefirot, was considered a fundamental and even indispensable work by later sages.

Rabbi Yehudah Leib Halevi Ashlag, also known as the Baal HaSulam, was a rabbi and a kabbalist. He was born In Lodz to a scholarly family connected to the Hasidic courts of Porisov and Belz. In 1921 he made aliyah, where he was appointed rabbi of Givat Shaul, Jerusalem. He is best known for his work Talmud Eser Sefirot, a commentary and re-editing of the work of Isaac Luria, as well as Sulam, a commentary on the Zohar.

R. Moshe de Leon was a Spanish rabbi and kabbalist. He wrote kabbalistic works which appeared under his name, but his most famous association is with the Zohar, which is attributed to the Tanna, Rabbi Shim'on bar Yochai. He was centrally involved in the emergence of the Zohar, and some attribute its composition, in part or in its entirety, to him. This association figured in controversies surrounding the Zohar shortly after it became widely know. He was widely knowledgeable both in philosophy and Kabbalah, and he was a gifted writer with a flair for the evocative turn of phrase. He dedicated two of his works to R. Todos HaLevi Abulafia. Most of his adult years he spend in Guadalajara, before moving to Avila in his latter years.

Rabbi Elazar ben Moshe Azikri was a kabbalist, preacher and poet of the Land of Israel. He lived and taught in Tzfat during its zenith in the 16th century. His family was expelled from Spain. He was one of a handful of rabbis to receive the renewed rabbinic semichah initiated by Rabbi Yaakov Berav. In 1588, he launched an effort to rouse many people to the penitence needed to hurry the redemption, called Sukkat Shalom. His famous work Sefer Charedim, a book which blends a halachic enumeration of the mitzvot with Kabbalist ethics, and is one of the central works of it genre, was part of that effort. His poem Yedid Nefesh, published in Sefer Charedim, is one of the most wellknown and beloved Hebrew poems. He also wrote talmudic commentaries.

Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneersohn was a Lithuanian rabbi, halakhic decisor and third rebbe of the Chabad Chassidic movement. His mother died shortly after his birth and was rasied by his grandfather, Rabbi Shneur Zalman, the Alter Rebbe of Chabad. After the death of his uncle, Rabbi Dov Baer, the mittle Rebbe, he tried unsuccessfully to persuade the Chassidim to accept other candidates as rebbe, and only acceded to their demands after three years. His many responsa were published in the influential work by which he is know, Tzemach Tzedek. He also wrote a mystical exposition of the mitzvot, Derech Mitzvotecha. In opposing the Haskalah, he formed a strong bond with prominent leaders of the Mitnagdim (opponents of Chassidism), which lead to a kind of rapprochement. He actively promoted the expansion of Chabad yeshivot in the towns in which there were concentrations of Chabad Chassidim, and he sent students to lift the spirits of young cantonist (boys taken into the Russian army with the intent of their eventual apostasy). He was succeeded as rebbe by his youngest son, Shmuel, while other sons set up competing Chabad courts some of which persisted untiil World War 2.
column11: Achronim

column10: Rebbe Levi Yitzchok of Berditchev, was also known as "The Berditchever Rabbi" after the community he served for 25 years . A childhood illuy (genius) from a prominent rabbinic family, he chose to study Chasidut under the Maggid of Mezritch for many years. His love of the Jewish people and his charitable interpretations of their actions before Hashem are legendery, as was as his fervor in prayer and enthusiastic dedication to mitzvot. He is the author of the Kedushat Levi, a collection of chasidic insights into the weekly Torah portion.
column19: Maggid of Mezritch, Shmekle of Nikolsburg,

column10: Rebbe Yitzchak Meir Rotenberg-Alter, also known as "The Rim," was the first rebbe of the Ger Hasidic dynasty. He was a Talmudic genius from a distinguished line of German and Polish rabbis that included Rashi and the Tosafist, Rabbi Meir ben Baruch of Rothenburg. His hasidut was influenced by the Koznitzer Maggid, Reb Simcha Bunim of Prshischa and the Kotzker Rebbe, of whom he was a disciple. He established his own dynasty in the Polish town of Góra Kalwaria, or "Ger," in Yiddish. He is known for his work Chiddushei HaRim.

Rabbi Yisroel (Israel) ben Eliezer, also known as the Baal Shem Tov (the Besh"t), was the founder of the Hasidic movement. Of humble and obscure origins, he was introduced to the secrets of kabbalah by Rabbi Adam Baal Shem of Ropczyce and other masters of practical kabbalah. In 1734 he presented himself to the world as a "Baal Shem," a "Master of the Name," the title used for holy men who could work miracles. His teachings made kabbalistic teachings accessibile to the common Jew, and emphasized ways of drawing closer to the Divine besides the traditional framework of Torah study. He was followed as leader of the nascent Hasidic movement by Rabbi Dov Baer the Maggid of Mezeritch.

column25: Brother in Law Abraham Gershon of Kitov

column10: Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, known as "The Rebbe," was the last Chabad-Lubavitcher rebbe and the pioneer of the Jewish outreach movement. Under his leadership, Chabad emerged from relative obscurity to become one of the most influential forces of Jewish life in the 20th century. Escaping Nazi Europe, he arrived in New York in 1941, where he became the head of Chabad's educational and social service networks. He immediately established the "shlichut" system, sending pairs of yeshiva students to far-flung Jewish communities to reconnect Jews to their heritage. He also worked actively internationally, helping to free thousands of Iranian Jews during the 1979 revolution, and later providing for the religious and educational needs of Jews trapped inside the Soviet Union.

Rabbi Yehudah Aryeh Leib Alter (the Sefat Emet) was a Polish rabbi and Chassidic master, third rebbe of the Gerer Chassidim. His father died while he was still a boy and he was raised by his grandfather, the Chiddushey HaRim. He also served as head of the town's beit din. Under his leadership, Ger became the largest and most influential Chassidic court in Poland. His many works are all called Sefat Emet, and they include a magisterial collection of Chassidic insight and teachings based on the weekly Torah portion. This work is widely studied throughout the Jewish world to this day. Unlike many Chassidic masters, he refused to accept money willingly given by his followers, and supported himself from a small store run by his wife. He was an opponent of the nascent Zionist movement.

Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin (1749-1821), popularly known as Reb Chaim, was the foremost disciple of the Vilna Gaon and the founder of the Volozhin Yeshiva. The yeshiva taught the Gaon's study method of penetrating analysis of the Talmud, a unique style which was then copied by all of the great Lithuanian yeshivas. Reb Chaim himself was also considered one of the greatest Talmudic scholars of his age. His major work is Nefesh HaChaim, an explication of Jewish belief.
column19: Aryeh Leib ben Asher Gunzberg, Vilna Gaon

column10: Rabbi Avraham ben Reb Nachman Chazan (1845-1917) was a Breslover rabbi known for his extreme asceticism. The son of a close disciple of Reb Noson, he passed on many of Breslov's oral traditions in his work Kokhvei Or. His Biur HaLikutim was a major and popular explication of Likutei Moharan.
column25: Son of Rebbe Nahman of Tulchin

column10: Rabbi Eliezer Papo (1785–1828) was a scholar noted for his piety and spirituality who authored books on halakhah, homiletics, and musar (ethics). He is best known for his book Pele Yoetz, a highly popular work of musar that deals with a wide variety of day-to-day Jewish living. He served as the rabbi of Silistra, Bulgaria, until his death in 1828. His grave in Silistra is a focus of pilgrimage.

Rabbi Nathaniel Weil was a rabbi and talmudic scholar. He was the son of R. Naphtali Zvi Hirsch Weil and the student R. Abraham Broda. He wrote several commentaries, including Korban Nethan'el, which is a commentary on Asher ben Jechiel. He served as rabbi in the Black Forest and in Karlsruhe, Germany.
column17: Henschel of Hainburg, Israel of Krems

column10: Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Waldenberg was a rabbi and dayan on the Supreme Rabbinical Court of Jerusalem and the foremost authority on medicine and halacha. He was known as the Tzitz Eliezer, after his monumental halachic treatise by that name, covering everything from Jewish ritual to medical ethics. It is widely considered to be one of the greatest halachic works of the 20th century.

Rabbi Menachem Nochum Twersky of Chernobyl, also known as the "Meor Einayim," was a student of the Baal Shem Tov and the Maggid of Mezritch. He was a gifted and enthusiastic orator for the early Hasidic movement. He became the maggid of Chernobyl and the founder of the Chernobyl dynasty, which includes many famous scions of the Twersky family.  He was the author of Meor Einayim, Chasidic insights into the weekly Torah portion and the holidays.
column19: Baal Shem Tov, Maggid of Mezritch

column10: Rabbi Nathaniel Weil was a rabbi and talmudic scholar. He was the son of R. Naphtali Zvi Hirsch Weil and the student R. Abraham Broda. He wrote several commentaries, including Korban Nethan'el, which is a commentary on Asher ben Jechiel. He served as rabbi in the Black Forest and in Karlsruhe, Germany.

Rabbi Jacob Schor was the rabbi of Brest-Litovsk and author of Be'it Yaakov, hiddushim on Sanhedrin. He was the son of Rabbi Solomon Ephraim (The Elder) Schor.  There is debate about the year of his death.  Some place it as 1654, some 1663.
Rabbi Shmuel Tzvi Danziger of Alexander (1860-1923), also known as the Tiferes Shmuel, was the third rebbe of the Alexander Hasidic dynasty and author of the Torah commentary Tiferes Shmuel.
column17: Shmuel Tzvi Dancyger, Yerachmiel Yisroel Yitzchak Danziger
column25: For a complete picture of his family c.f Wikipedia

column10: Rabbi David Zvi Hoffmann was the leading authority on halakha in Germany during his lifetime and a leading expert on midrash halakha. He had a doctorate from the University of Tubingen and taught Talmud, Halakha and Tanach in the rabbinical school of Rabbi Azriel Hildescheimer in Berlin, later becoming head of the Seminary. He was known for his scholarly refutations of the Documentary Hypothesis.

Rabbi Joshua ben Alexander HaCohen Falk was a posek and Talmud scholar. He learned with his relative Moses Isserles and with Solomon Luria and later became the head of the Yeshiva of Lemberg. He is best known for his works Beit Yisrael, a commentary on Arba'ah Turim, and Sefer Me'irat Enayim on Shulchan Aruch.
column25: Related to Moses Isserles and Shlomo Luria

column1: Aharon ben Jacob Ha-Kohen of Lunil
column3: אהרון בן יעקוב הכהן מן לונין
column10: Rabbi Aharon ben Jacob Ha-Kohen was a 13th/14th century rabbi from the Provence and later Majorca. His work, Orchot Chaim, was a compilation and commentary on the laws of prayer, Shabbat, and the festivals. Though superceded by later works, it contains unique mystical and ethical insights.

Rabbi Yehudah Yudel Rosenberg, was also known as Rav Yudel Tarlow'er, after the town of Tarlow where he served as rabbi. He was born into a rabbinical family that claimed descent from Yehuda Hasid. In addition to a thorough traditional education, he learned Hebrew literature and encouraged it's revival. In 1913 he emigrated to Toronto, where he became the rabbi of the Beth Jacob congregation. He was a prolific author, perhaps best known for his translation of the Zohar into Hebrew.

Rabbi Eleazar ben Judah ben Kalonymos (c.1160-1238), also known as Eleazar of Worms or Eleazar Rokeach, was a major Talmud scholar and mystic and the last major member of the Hasidei Ashkenaz. He was a prolific author, providing most of the movementls extant pietistic and ethical literature. He also wrote Tosafot to many Talmudic tractates, which were referred to by Bezalel Ashkenazi in his Shiṭṭah Meḳubbeẓet.

Rabbi Isaac Samuel Reggio, also known as the YaShaR, was a linguist, scholar and religious philosopher who applied the principles of enlightenment philosophy to the understanding of Torah. He sought to establish a rabbinical seminary in Italy and promoted the teaching of Hebrew to the masses. Partly to that end, he translated the Pentateuch into Italian and provided his own Hebrew commentary.

column1: Isaac ben Meir Halevi from Düren
column3: יצחק בן רבי מאיר הלוי מדורא
column10: Rabbi Isaac ben Meir of Dueren was one of the leading Talmudic authorities of the second half of the 13th century. His work Sha'arei Dura was the authoritative codification of the dietary laws until the Shulchan Aruch.

Rabbi Hayyim ben Yosef Vital was the foremost disciple of Rabbi Isaac Luria of Tzfat, whose teachings he recorded and edited. They were later re-edited by his son, Rabbi Shmuel Vital, in the eight volume work Shemona She’arim. He also authored many of his own works, including commentaries, responsa and practical kabbala.

Rabbi Zerahiah the Greek was a Jewish ethicist of the Byzantine Empire in the thirteenth or fourteenth century. He is sometimes referred to by his acronymistic name, the "Ra'Za'H." His book Sefer HaYashar, which is often confused with other works by that name, consists of 18 chapters dealing with the ethical principles underlying man's relationship to God.

Rabbi Yehudah ben Shimon Ashkenazi was born in Frankfort and served as a dayan on the rabbinical court in Tykocin, Poland. He is best known as the co-author of the Ba'er Heitev, a major commentary on the Shulchan Aruch.

Yannai was a payyetan (liturgical poet) of the first half of the 7th century, who may have lived in Eretz Yisrael. He was the first to use rhyme and introduced the convention of using his name in acrostics. He may have been the composer of the Unettaneh Tokef prayer.

Rabbi Aaron Samuel ben Israel Kaidanover was a Polish-Lithuanian rabbi. Among his works were responsa, annotations on the Talmudic tractates of  Kedoshim, a commentary on Piskei HaRosh, and a partly kabbalistic commentary on the Chumash. He was the rabbi of Cracow at the time of his death.

Aharon ben Joseph HaLevi, known as the Ra'ah (רא"ה), was a Talmudic scholar, halakhist and rabbi. He was born in Gerona, Spain to a long line of rabbis reaching back to the Baal HaMaor.  He studied with his father, Rabbi Joseph HaLevi, as well as with Nachmanides. His best-known work is Bedek Habayit, critical notes on the Rashba's Torat HaBayit. He also wrote Talmudic commentaries. He had been claimed as the author of Sefer HaChinuch, but this identification is considered erroneous.

Rabbi Bahya ben Asher ibn Halawa (1255-1340), also known as Rabbeinu Behaye, was a Spanish rabbi, scholar and Biblical commentator. He was a pupil of Rabbi Shlomo ben Aderet, and modeled his exegitical style on that of Nachmanides. He was the first to build his commentary on the four principles denoted by the letters PaRDeS, "Peshat, Remez, Drush, Sod:" 1) the plain text, 2) a deeper, more philosophical approach to the text; 3) homiletical approach to the text; and 4) a mystical kabbalistic interpretation of the text. The work Chovot Halevavot is sometimes inaccurately ascribed to him.
